name: Sheermal
history: Originating from the Persian influence on Indian cuisine, Sheermal is a traditional saffron-flavored flatbread.
description: Sheermal is a rich, sweet flatbread made with flour, milk, saffron, and ghee. It's typically served with spicy curries or enjoyed as a delicacy on its own.

equipment.name: rolling pin
equipment.description: Used for rolling out the dough.

equipment.name: baking tray
equipment.description: Used for placing the sheermal before baking.

equipment.name: pastry brush
equipment.description: Used for applying milk and saffron mixture on the sheermal.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: Dissolve yeast and a pinch of sugar in warm milk. Let it sit until frothy. In a bowl, mix flour, sugar, salt, cardamom powder, and ghee. Add the yeast mixture and knead into a soft dough. Cover and let it rest for an hour.

instructions.title: Prepare Saffron Mixture
instructions.description: Soak saffron in 1 tablespoon of warm milk.

instructions.title: Shape the Sheermal
instructions.description: Preheat the oven to 200Â°C (400Â°F). Roll the dough into a round shape and place it on a baking tray.

instructions.title: Bake
instructions.description: Brush the rolled dough with the saffron-infused milk. Bake for 15 minutes or until golden brown.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the sheermal warm. It can be enjoyed with tea, coffee, or a savory dish.

tips: Kneading the dough well is key to a soft sheermal.
The dough should be slightly sticky for the right texture.
variations: Add nuts or dried fruits to the dough for a different flavor.
Replace sugar with honey for a different kind of sweetness.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh, but can be stored for up to 2 days in an airtight container.
storage.instructions: Reheat in an oven or on a skillet before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Warm in an oven or on a skillet until soft and heated through.
presentationTips: Serve on a decorative plate with a garnish of powdered sugar or sliced almonds.
